content.text: The word "computer" originally referred to a person who performed calculations. Before electronic machines, human computers were employed to solve complex mathematical problems, especially during wartime for calculating artillery trajectories and breaking enemy codes.
Today, we define a computer as an electronic device that can store, retrieve, and process data according to a set of instructions called a program.
1. Ancient Calculating Tools (3000 BC - 1600 AD)

content.caption: The abacus: one of the earliest calculating devices, still used today

content.text: The journey began with simple counting tools like the abacus, invented around 3000 BC. These mechanical devices helped humans perform basic arithmetic operations much faster than mental calculation alone.
2. Mechanical Computers (1600s - 1800s)

content.caption: Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine - the first design for a general-purpose computer

content.text: Charles Babbage designed the Analytical Engine in the 1830s, which is considered the first design for a general-purpose computer. It included all the basic elements of a modern computer: input devices, memory, a central processing unit, and output devices.
3. Electromechanical Era (1930s - 1940s)
The 1930s saw the development of electromechanical computers that used electrical switches and mechanical relays. These machines could perform calculations much faster than purely mechanical devices.
4. Electronic Computers (1940s - 1950s)

content.caption: ENIAC (1946) - one of the first general-purpose electronic computers

content.text: ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer), completed in 1946, was one of the first general-purpose electronic computers. It weighed 30 tons, occupied 1,800 square feet, and used 18,000 vacuum tubes.
5. Transistor Revolution (1950s - 1960s)

content.caption: The transistor replaced vacuum tubes, making computers smaller and more reliable

content.text: The invention of the transistor in 1947 revolutionized computing. Transistors were smaller, more reliable, and consumed less power than vacuum tubes, leading to the second generation of computers.
6. Integrated Circuits and Microprocessors (1960s - Present)

content.caption: Modern microprocessors contain billions of transistors on a single chip

content.text: The development of integrated circuits (microchips) in the 1960s and microprocessors in the 1970s led to personal computers. Today's smartphones have more computing power than the room-sized computers of the 1940s.

content.caption: The IPO model: input → processing → output

content.text: Old definition: In early computing, an 'operation' meant a basic arithmetic or tabulation step carried out by people or electromechanical devices. Each operation was a single manual/mechanical action like adding, subtracting, or moving values on a register.

Current definition: In modern computing, an operation is any transformation a computer performs on data under program control — arithmetic, logic, data movement, storage, and retrieval. Operations are executed as CPU instructions, orchestrated by algorithms.
These operations are best understood through the IPO concept:

items: Input: Data enters the system (keyboard, sensors, files, network).
Processing: The CPU executes instructions to transform the input using algorithms.
Output: The results are presented or stored (screen, sound, files, databases).

points: The word 'computer' originally referred to people who performed calculations
Computing evolved from mechanical devices (abacus) to electronic machines
Key milestones: Analytical Engine (1830s), ENIAC (1946), transistor (1947), microprocessor (1970s)
Each generation became smaller, faster, and more powerful
Modern computers can perform billions of operations per second

content.text: ENIAC (1946): 5,000 operations per second, 30 tons, room-sized
Modern smartphone: Billions of operations per second, 200 grams, pocket-sized
Your phone is literally millions of times more powerful than the computers that helped win World War II!
